description:
This addresses an issue I recently discovered that the LOS velocity calculation is off by a factor of -1 relative to the calculated LightRay objects.  Statistically this does nothing, but it affects things on individual sightlines.

As an example, here is a ray overplot on a slice with velocity vectors *with* this PR code (observer sits at the top looking down):

http://i.imgur.com/7lu1bTn.png

And here is information about the ray--the top two panels are relevant and show the ray in terms of absorbers being red/blue shifted relative to the observer: 

http://i.imgur.com/8LS5dT2.png
title: LightRay was using reverse of LOS velocity.

pullrequest.title: LightRay was using reverse of LOS velocity.

content.raw:
The reason this works is a bit counter-intuitive.  It's because we increment down in redshift from the start of the ray to the end, whereas normally one would think of the redshift increasing with increasing distance from the observer.  This is a carry-over from the fact that cosmological light rays (spanning multiple datasets) start at the highest redshift and work their way down.  Since this change will make both single dataset and cosmological rays consistent, I think we should go with this rather than reversing the redshift increment, but perhaps a comment could be added as to why this is seemingly done opposite of what one would expect.

I think with that done, this should go in sooner rather than later as this should be considered a bugfix.
content.html:
The reason this works is a bit counter-intuitive. It's because we increment down in redshift from the start of the ray to the end, whereas normally one would think of the redshift increasing with increasing distance from the observer. This is a carry-over from the fact that cosmological light rays (spanning multiple datasets) start at the highest redshift and work their way down. Since this change will make both single dataset and cosmological rays consistent, I think we should go with this rather than reversing the redshift increment, but perhaps a comment could be added as to why this is seemingly done opposite of what one would expect.

I think with that done, this should go in sooner rather than later as this should be considered a bugfix.

pullrequest.title: LightRay was using reverse of LOS velocity.

content.raw: We've had a large number of bugfixes for this specific section of code in the last few weeks.  I'd really like to see tests get added before we continue adding bugfixes, and if those tests can function as unit tests rather than answer tests that would be preferable.  Particularly because Cameron is concerned that the API and functionality don't "break Trident" in the future, I think that it should be a priority to add tests.
content.html: We've had a large number of bugfixes for this specific section of code in the last few weeks. I'd really like to see tests get added before we continue adding bugfixes, and if those tests can function as unit tests rather than answer tests that would be preferable. Particularly because Cameron is concerned that the API and functionality don't "break Trident" in the future, I think that it should be a priority to add tests.

pullrequest.title: LightRay was using reverse of LOS velocity.

content.raw:
This test will not be a unit test, it will be an answer test.  There is no a priori way of knowing what a dataset's velocity field will look like to see if it is reversed or not.

As I said, it is a priority to make tests for the two relevant analysis modules which have no automatic testing currently.  However, it seems very unusual for bugfix PRs to be required to have tests added.
content.html:
This test will not be a unit test, it will be an answer test. There is no a priori way of knowing what a dataset's velocity field will look like to see if it is reversed or not.

As I said, it is a priority to make tests for the two relevant analysis modules which have no automatic testing currently. However, it seems very unusual for bugfix PRs to be required to have tests added.

pullrequest.title: LightRay was using reverse of LOS velocity.

content.raw: Maybe there are a couple easy unit tests we could set up.  Could we create a fake uniform grid and set the velocity field to be uniform and all in the positive direction?  We could then test that the line of sight velocity always has the correct sign and perhaps also test that the total column is value of a uniform density times the total length of the ray.  Other than things like this, it's hard to imagine other unit tests that could be added.
content.html: Maybe there are a couple easy unit tests we could set up. Could we create a fake uniform grid and set the velocity field to be uniform and all in the positive direction? We could then test that the line of sight velocity always has the correct sign and perhaps also test that the total column is value of a uniform density times the total length of the ray. Other than things like this, it's hard to imagine other unit tests that could be added.

pullrequest.title: LightRay was using reverse of LOS velocity.

content.raw: To make it a unit test, you could create a dataset with a known field (for instance, all zeros or all ones) and verify that it results in what you are hoping for.  Answer testing is a good way to make sure there are no regressions in the results -- but it seems even that would not have caught the last several sets of bugs -- but unit testing with known, constructed and arbitrary fields can ensure that the functionality is actually correct.
content.html: To make it a unit test, you could create a dataset with a known field (for instance, all zeros or all ones) and verify that it results in what you are hoping for. Answer testing is a good way to make sure there are no regressions in the results -- but it seems even that would not have caught the last several sets of bugs -- but unit testing with known, constructed and arbitrary fields can ensure that the functionality is actually correct.
